facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1887 of 1967 is an appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated 20th December 1963 of the Kerala High Court in A.S. No. 54 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1887 of 1967 Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 20th December, 1963 of the Kerala High Court at Eranakulam in A. S. No. 54 of 1959.

facts.text: Dr. Krishnan died in England on October 18, 1950 intestate.

anchor.surface_text: from a decree in a suit for partition of- the assets of one Dr. Krishnan who died in England on October 18, 1950, according to the provisions of the Travancore Ezhava Act and the dispute between the parties number is companyrned with the question of succession to the sale proceeds of the movable and other moneys included in Schedule-C to the plaint.

facts.text: Krishnan had two brothers, Padmanabhan and Govindan (first defendant), and a sister (second defendant).

anchor.surface_text: Krishnan had two brothers, namely, Padmanabhan and Govindan, the first defendant, and a sister, the second defendant.

facts.text: Krishnan went to England in 1920 for higher studies in medicine.

anchor.surface_text: Krishnan went to England in 1920 for higher studies in medicine.

facts.text: Krishnan set up practice at Sheffield and purchased a building at 75 Woodhouse Road, Sheffield.

anchor.surface_text: When Krishnan became qualified to practise medicine, he set up practice at Sheffield and in companyrse of time he was able to build up a good practice. He was later employed in the, National Health Scheme. He purchased a building viz., 75- Wood house Road, Sheffield, where he carried on his profession.

facts.text: First defendant (Govindan) came to England by end of 1949 and returned to India without Krishnan.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant-appellant came to England both for the purpose of qualifying himself for F.R.C.S, and for taking back Krishnan to India. He prosecuted his studies in England for which Krishnan helped him with money and, by the end of 1949, he returned to India.

facts.text: Suit for partition of assets including Schedules A, B, and later C (sale proceeds from England).

anchor.surface_text: In the suit, as originally framed, the plaintiffs claimed partition ,of the items mentioned in Schedules A and B of the plaint. After the institution of the suit, proceedings were started in England...

facts.text: Defendants 22 and 23 are administrators Arksey and Mary Woodliff appointed by English High Court, impleaded in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 22 and 23 are Mr. Cyrin Lawlin Arksey and Miss Mary Woodliff, the administrators of Krishnans estate, appointed by the High Court of Judicature in England and they were impleaded in the suit some time in 1953,

facts.text: English High Court by Ex. 56 order held Krishnan domiciled in England.

anchor.surface_text: By ex. 56 order, the High Court held that Krishnan died domiciled in England.

facts.text: Trial court held Krishnan not domiciled in England, Ex.56 obtained by fraud, opposed to natural justice, no res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt overruled the companytention of the first defendant and held that Krishnan was number domiciled in England at the time of his death, that ex. 56 order was obtained by fraud, that the proceedings which culminated in ex. 56 order were opposed to natural justice

facts.text: Kerala High Court confirmed trial court: not domiciled, fraud, no natural justice, partition per Ezhava Act, but house proceeds to next of kin.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyfirmed the finding of the trial companyrt that Krishnan was number domiciled in England, that ex. 56 order was obtained by fraud of the appellant, that the proceedings in which ex. 56 order was obtained were opposed to the principles of natural justice...

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Ex.56 not obtained by fraud, proceedings not opposed to natural justice for majors.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we think the High Court was number justified in imputing fraud to the first defendant in procuring ex. 56 order.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds Krishnan died domiciled in England based on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: on the evidence in this case, which we have already discussed in detail, that Krishnan had numbersettled or definite intention to return to Travancore and that, as he was a resident in England... he died domiciled in England.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Ex.56 invalid against minors due to no jurisdiction/submission.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we do number think that the ex. 56 order was valid as ,against the minors.

facts.text: Succession to movables/moneys (Schedule C minus house) governed by English law, to first and second defendants.

anchor.surface_text: we hold that the succession to the amount specified in Schedule-C minus the amount which represents the sale proceeds of the, house property in Sheffield must also be governed by English law and that the amount must be distributed between the first and second defendants in equal shares.

facts.text: Krishnan had no wife and no children.

anchor.surface_text: Krishnan died suddenly in England on October 18, 1950 intestate. He had numberwife and children

facts.text: First defendant executed power of attorney for administrators to obtain letters of administration in England.

anchor.surface_text: proceedings were started in England by Arksey and Mary Woodliff on the basis of a power of attorney executed by the appellant for obtaining letters of administration of the estate of Krishnan.

facts.text: Notices of English proceedings served on natural guardians of minors, who did not appear for them; official solicitor appointed.

anchor.surface_text: numberices of the proceedings were served upon all the parties to the present suit, the numberices to the minors being served on their natural guardians. The parties appeared before the High Court...

facts.text: Trial court and High Court concurrent finding that deceased intended to return to India (disputed by appellant).

anchor.surface_text: There is overwhelming evidence and also companycurrent finding by both the trial Court and the High Court that the deceased had the intention of returning to India and settle down here.

facts.text: Appellant argued no fraud or violation of natural justice in English proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberpleading regarding the judgment having been obtained by fraud, or being opposed to natural justice... The appellant gave information regarding the assets of the deceased in India and his relatives in India.

facts.text: 17 infants/minors involved, notices served on fathers who did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The infants who were as many as 17 had number submitted to the jurisdiction of the English companyrt. Notices issued by the English Court were served on the fathers of these infants who never appeared on their behalf

facts.text: Letters of administration issued to Arksey and Mary Woodliff.

anchor.surface_text: Letters of administration were issued in their favour.

facts.text: House at 75-Woodhouse Road and movables sold, proceeds to def 1 and 2 on indemnity bond.

anchor.surface_text: The house and the movable in England were sold and the proceeds together with the moneys were handed over to defendants 1 and 2 after taking from them a bond of indemnity.

facts.text: Padmanabhan managed Krishnan's share of family properties till his death.

anchor.surface_text: While Krishnan was away in England, a partition took place in his family and a share in the properties of the family was allotted to him. Padmanabhan, his elder, brother, was managing the properties till his death.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal allowed, no costs.

anchor.surface_text: We allow the appeal but make numberorder as to companyts.
